summary: After his release from prison, Jake (John Belushi) reunites with his brother, Elwood (Dan Aykroyd) -- collectively known as the "Blues Brothers." Jake's first task is to save the orphanage the brothers grew up in from closing, by raising $5,000 to pay back taxes. The two are convinced they can earn the money by getting their old band back together. However, after playing several gigs and making a few enemies, including the police, the brothers face daunting odds to deliver the money on time.

reviews.content: perfect for 10+ years old who like explosions and car chases and police
Goofy police car scene.

Don't know why so many love this movie. It's mostly devoid of comedy, wow the law is after them in excess, so funny. That got old before I even saw it. Watching Jake & Elwood sing, dance, cars smashing into things, a burn unit at a hospital is more amusing. Sorry I forgot, boring asf.

Commedia musicale semplicemente iconica e meravigliosa.
Due dei personaggi che hanno segnato la storia del cinema per il look impareggiabile e per i loro modi di fare assurdi ed unici.
La qualità estrema del film, oltre che nella coppia di attori, è nella musica.
Tutto è infatti subordinato all'inarrivabile perfezione delle sequenze musicali, in cui i due strepitosi protagonisti sono costantemente supportati dai più grandi musicisti del tempo.
Il resto della sceneggiatura è solamente un contorno per permettere ai comprimari di presentarsi ed ai protagonisti di sviluppare la loro musica.
La sensazione è quella di un'irrefrenabile voglia di vedere i Blues Brothers sul palco, dove il loro magnetismo è incontenibile.
Alcune sequenze di dialoghi sono molto bizzarre, un paio evitabili per banalità.
One of my all time top 10 movies must watch. Wachten it when I was younger and still enjoy it every time

One of my favourite movies ever.
The main characters are so iconic, the crescendo of chaos around them so perfectly absurd, their expressions so perfectly unmoved by the absolute madness... and good music to complete it all!

Easily one of the greatest movie soundtracks of all time. This movie is a cult classic for those of us that grew up in Illinois. The movie is supposed to be over the top with the car chases and the obnoxious characters. If you don’t understand that then this movie isn’t for you. I HATE ILLINOIS NAZIS!

A Classic Musical Comedy Action Hybrid. This movie is nothing but one fun silly over the top ride the whole way through. The acting is good overall but not stellar, and the pacing struggles a bit in the middle of the film feeling about 15 minutes too long. Its very bloated and over the top the whole way through. That being said, the Songs are all incredible, the action chases are entertaining and make you go wow while your laughing how over the top it all is. The editing very well done as well. Overall it all comes together to a really fun and memorable time never feeling generic. The Key here is how self aware the film is never taking itself too serious with its All Star Cast. While this the bare minimum for being a Musical I would still call this a classic of its genre with a good amount of minor flaws. A Very Fun and Memorable Time.

This film is so bad! 99% of the movie is unfunny. The only worthwhile scenes in the film are the ones with Aretha Franklin and James Brown. Almost the entire film is utterly boring. Too much car chasing scenes. The police chase at the end was way too long and without laughs. I can't believe with Ackroyd and Belushi they couldn't make it funny.

Some films don't age well, but this one is, if anything, even more enjoyable to watch now than it was when it first came out around 40 years ago.  Belushi and Ackroyd are at their peak-performance best.  And Carrie Fisher of Star Wars fame plays Belushi's completely psychotic jilted girlfriend!  See if you can spot the Steven Spielberg cameo near the end. "Illinois Nazis.  I hate Illinois Nazis."
It's my favourite movie. I like the music and the other things to

The greatest 02 hours: and 13 minutes ever!!!!!!!!!!! Starring Dan Aykroyd, the late John Belushi, the late James Brown, the late Ray Charles Robinson, the late Aretha Franklin, and the late Cab Calloway!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Also starring the late Carrie Fisher, and the late John Candy!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Great classic comedy.   One of the 10 best of all time.
My favorite film of all time. The comedy, the stunts, the music, the actors. This is a movie all remember forever
An amazing experience and quite an adventure through rock and roll.
Una comedia que quizá en pleno 2022 no funcione igual que antes, pero en la cual se aprecia la genialidad de este par de iconos. Contiene escenas verdaderamente hilarantes.
I watched this film for the first time as a 5 year-old! It is so amazing how hooked I was  on a premise that was 100% not targeted towards me. I would say it is defiantly better on rewatch!
Pure musical madness.
This movie is by far my favorite. With a church, Chicago, Fischer, and every law enforcement agency you can think of, this movie is a must see. Not to mention, the jailhouse rock at the end.

Watched all of this highly rated classic hoping it would get better. It didn't. The film only has 2 things going for it: the car chase stunts, and the music. The acting is bad; if it ever was funny it sure isn't now; everything is OTT but in an unfunny way. My advice is to listen to the soundtrack but give the film a miss.

This movie is a landmark-it was responsible for Chicago becoming the setting for a number of future movies. On its own, it is based on a Saturday Night Live sketch about two white characters with pretensions of being blues musicians. Add a number of major real-life blues musicians and an even larger number of car crashes, and that's the recipe for the movie.

The premise is about two brothers, one just out of Joliet prison, who try to raise money to save an orphanage from closing down, and to do so, bring together the members of their old band. Of course, their efforts to do so end up causing trouble with the law, as well as other people (such as a country and western-themed bar and the band that was supposed to play there). In the end, dozens of police cars chase after them, and even the National Guard, before they fulfill their quest. There are some genuinely funny parts, but overall the whole movie depends on exaggeration-twenty police cars crashing into twenty police cars, as critic Roger Ebert had put it.

40 years in and this hilarious musical farce remains as fresh as the first time I saw it.  It has its "haters" I'm sure, but that's because its humour skewers the pretentious and the politically correct at every turn.  Set those affectations aside and there are multiple layers on which to enjoy this movie.  Who knew actors could sing?  Who knew blues musicians could act?  Who knew they could all dance so well?  Marvel at the comedic timing & instincts of John Belushi & Dan Ackroyd, at the absolute top of their game.  Glory in the great R&B numbers, delivered by the industry legends who made these hits.  Reflect on some of the subtle social commentary layered in beneath the farce.  Most of all, if you can't tap your toes to this one, you better check for a pulse!
Who cannot love these two SNL actors that struck it big in this farcical movie!
Loved it! Great song playlist throughout the movie. Loved the characters and the chemistry they had. What a classic!!
A must see film for classic American music lovers! Plus absolutely hilarious!!
Fun film to watch with a great soundtrack!!!  One of Belushi and Akroyd's best performances.  The car chases are top notch as well.  Overall, I recommend this one.
Ray Charles & Aretha Franklin in great form.
This classic is easily my favourite musical of all time. Akyroyd and Belushi have amazing chemistry. Featuring an all-star cast it can't be beat.
The last of an era and has some peng tracks, the best of the 80's
Such a classic, everyone is great in this movie, so well directed, just entertaining from start to finish.  Wish Hollywood still made movies like this.

Blues Brothers features some KILLER musical numbers featuring some of the greatest performers of all time (Franklin, Brown, Charles & more). The superstar cameos are like a walk through the memory lane of America's great Blues, R&B, & Soul legends. The humor big, insane, and over the top. The practical stunts & explosions are massive and continue to up the ante throughout the film, just when you thought it couldn't get any bigger- it does. They must have destroyed nearly 100 vehicles in the making of the movie, and several buildings also get obliterated- all for the sake of comedic slapstick action. It does become a bit exhausting towards the end of its 150 minute runtime, as the final chase scene becomes more, and more bombastic and large scale. Most of the situational humor is genuinely funny, although it can become a bit much at times. The big moments (where cars are crashing, buildings and getting smashed, and our protagonists continue to be unfazed by the madness around them) cause some big laughter. Aretha Franklin has the standout musical number in my opinion- although seeing James Brown, Ray Charles, John Lee Hooker was also a blast. I think they could've shaved off 20-30 minutes and the movie would be paced a little better- the big cameo numbers are pretty much done by the end of the second act and since for me- those were the high points- the third act drags on a bit. But overall it is a fun ride, and especially for lovers of music. It's also fun to see Carrie Fisher play a psychotic, bitter, & violent ex-lover to Belushi.
In memory of Ray Charles and John Belushi!!!!!!!!!!!

It's too long. There's too many scenes which add no value. BUT the music is magical, the main characters are spot on and ultimately this is a fabulous feel good film which never fails to make you feel positive.

Fueled by tons of cocaine - or so legend say - Landis and his cast and crew never thought anything would be too over the top... and for some cosmic coincidence, they were right. Featuring awesome music cameos, and hilarious twists and turns, and total disregard for logic, physics or common sense, the movie is a pure joy to watch.
This movie has become so iconic that you must see it at least once. The lack of plot and continuity is truly overshadowed by Belushi and Aykroyd and all the cameos.

It took me a few minutes to sink into the vibe that this film was going for, but once I had the right mindset, this was a blast. The music is phenomenal and the guest stars keep every scene feeling unique. Aykroyd and Belushi's completely straight performances bring out the surreality of the story. Ever escalating into absurdity, The Blues Brothers is a cult classic for anyone.
Amazing feel good movie!!
Everybody needs somebody to bring a little fun into their lives, and the Blues Brothers are the guys for the job.

An absoulute classic. Blues Brothers is a perfect movie. It is hilarious, it has action, the (sort of anthology because of the interferences with the Good Ol' Boys, the Neo-Nazi's, the police, and others) stories are all woven together perfectly, and the music. Oh the music. You will feel like you are at the worlds best concert. Eat your heart out Hamilton, this is the best musical ever made. Blues Brothers is the best. 

Edit): If you are a parent considering showing you kid Blues Brothers, I'd say 10 and up is an acceptable age.

Nothing outweighs the joy brought by the smiles of the Blues Brothers… ever so rarely seen. It's silly, senseless and the cream of screwball comedy. It's a ta…ll tale manifesting the joking without the jokes, true to every nuance.

Divertida, épica, muy entretenida y con buena música, es una de las mejores comedias de la historia del cine.
¡TOTALMENTE RECOMENDADA!

Ok mediocre movie starring John belushi and Dan I can't spell his last name aka the guy from Ghostbusters. I'm not a big blues or jazz person so the movie doesn't really connect with me like it did my dad. I'll most likely forget about this movie.

Although its soundtrack is excellent and the musical sequences are infectiously energetic and fun, the action and comedy scenes in The Blues Brothers are nothing of the sort – they are too ridiculous and dumb to be taken seriously. The movie overall is very mediocre as its plot is silly and the runtime is needlessly excessive, making it quite repetitious and badly paced.
Lots of fun! Can’t believe it was 40 years ago. Might not be able to watch this in the near future 😢

must see classic, seen about a dozen times, never bores
show it to your kids someday, as an education in music for one thing
Classic...yes. Rememberable or noteworthy...afraid not.
Some chase scenes go on too long but the rest is fantastic.

I don't know... certain John Landis movies just don't seem to have aged well. Or maybe it's just because I was never a big fan of Belushi. It's a zany caper that works for the most part, but a lot of the gags just don't really land for me. Though, I will say, the musical numbers are great and the action set pieces are insane.

A chaotic ride full of blues and soul.

John Landis' absurdist musical comedy The Blues Brothers (1980) is really hilarious. John Landis goes all out with his cozy Chicago feel and reckless madness with his direction. Landis uses his dry humor with a dramatic tone that kicks into gear with insanely dangerous car chases, brutal stunts, powerful live performances, and deadpan delivery of the two charismatic leads. Landis' direction is very steady as he takes you on a joy ride around Chicago and Illinois. His close-ups are very fun, but his wide shots during the car chases and mall wrecking sequences are impressive. How Landis even managed to get all those police cars, the tank, and the army extras for that finale is beyond me.

John Landis is clearly quite funny. His sense of humor is so silly and endearing that you cannot help but love The Blues Brothers. They were sent on a holy mission from God after all. John Landis wrote The Blues Brothers with the scatterbrained Dan Aykroyd for a feast of action, witty deadpan humor, and a love of Chicago blues. The Blues Brothers is certainly John Landis' greatest film with poignant soul songs to energetic blues tunes, The Blues Brothers has it all!

Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi kill it as Elwood Blues and Jake Blues. Aykroyd's manic goofball is gone and replaced by a stoic anti-hero and crazy car driver with a hilarious deadpan delivery that makes Elwood so funny. Belushi's anger and frustration as Jake is very funny, and he's amazing as he pleads for forgiveness from Carrie Fisher. Aykroyd and Belushi have this lackadaisical rapport and comedic chemistry that cannot be replicated. Deborah Nadoolman's iconic black suits for Elwood and Jake are still cool to me. 

I must mention the cast of celebrity cameos is astounding as John Landis gets everyone from Cab Calloway and James Brown to Aretha Franklin and Ray Charles. John Candy has a great cameo as a confident cop. John Lee Hooker's street performance is pure blues as far as I'm concerned. Twiggy and Carrie Fisher's cameo scenes are very cute. Look carefully and see if you can spot Frank Oz, Steven Spielberg, and even John Landis himself! In all, The Blues Brothers' cast is second to none.

George Folsey Jr.'s editing saves The Blues Brothers' massive 148 minute long run-time. He cuts away from any scene that drags, but he does let the songs just play out for your enjoyment. Stephen M. Katz' cinematography is really pretty and gritty. His tender close-up shots of Elwood and Jake as they struggle to drive around and form their band is really neat. Katz' shots during the car chases are too wild. He shoots with a Chicago breakneck style like Risky Business or Ferris Bueller's Day Off. You can clearly see The Blues Brothers' influence on these films as well as Ghostbusters, Tenacious D, Wayne's World, and Canadian Bacon among others. Elmer Berstein's score is very nice and subdued for such an absurd comedy.

In all, The Blues Brothers holds up nicely.

The Blues Brothers was awesome. Seriously. The choreography, performances, songs, comedy, cinematography and over-the-top car chases with more property damage than a superhero movie make one of the earliest SNL film adaptations a...you guessed it...timeless classic.
Although it's sometimes over the top, it has a solid and charming cast and catchy musical numbers.

"My own brother picks me up in a police car" John Landis's classic comedy musical with Belushi (Jake) & Aykroyd (Elwood) collectively known as the blues brothers a blues & soul duo who are on a mission from God to save a local orphanage. The two are convinced they can raise the money by getting there band back together. But on the way they make quite a few enemy's.

This movie does a great job making me laugh. The soundtrack is very catchy. Lines like "we're getting the band back together" and "we're on a mission from God" are lines I absolutely love. The thing I love about this movie the most is the third act. It always make me laugh! Great movie

The most unrealistic part of this entire movie is how little Chicago traffic there is.

All joking aside, The Blues Brothers is a great movie and deserves its place in one of the top 80's movies of all time. This film takes away the seriousness and allows some escapism from everyday life. The scale of some of the over-the-top practical stunts and amazing musical talent makes this movie nothing short of a masterpiece.

The plot is a real simple one. The Blues Brothers must raise $5,000 to save their childhood orphanage from being taken by the state. Along the way, the brothers get chased by cops, Nazis, and a crazy ex-girlfriend. Even with the world against them, the brothers cannot fail because they know that they're "on a mission from God." Lots of real chemistry and subplots between each character in the movie add to the fun.

All the cameos and star-spotting is extra fun. See some beautiful musical talent perform in their prime.

Lots of inside jokes that come after multiple viewings add to the rewatchability.

5/5. One of the most memorable comedy films I have ever watched. Instant classic for sure!

Did "The Blues Brothers" introduce millions of white Americans to the African-American art form of the blues? Factually, that's likely tough to argue with. Over forty years later, is it at all regrettable that a blues band fronted by two white comedians had to serve as its catalyst for crossing over into the larger cultural conversation?

Hindsight is always 20/20, and 1980 was the proverbial different world then. But with the possible exception of similarly stark white blues champions The Rolling Stones, one could argue that no musical or cinematic vehicle has so successfully introduced the brilliance of an underrepresented art form to such a massive crossover audience. Granted, there's not much question that bits of "The Blues Brothers" now feel like we're watching something being worn that's been borrowed from someone else's closet (see: the church and street market scenes). Then again, there's also little question that Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi are emotionally entrenched in these transformative tunes (they started the Blues Brothers band before the film took form, and it was loaded with African-American blues legends). Nor is it in doubt that this music comedy almost singularly kicked in the door to allow an army of descendant films to pour in.

Perhaps there's an argument that one way or the other, "The Blues Brothers" has become even more engrossing today exactly because of these nuanced dynamics. Play it loud and find out. - WATCHED IT? THEN WATCHLIST: "Stadium Anthems," "Sausage Party," "South Park: Bigger, Longer, and Uncut."
Stacked with pioneering 80s action comedy cliches, yet still fun, light, interesting, and exciting, this cult classic earns its status with its campy cop duo embedding themselves into pop culture.

One of my favourite films of all time. John Landis and Dan Aykroyd have written one of only two musicals that I actually like. The other being Grease (1978) 

The Blues Brothers has some over the top moments in it. Which in my opinion only add to its excitement. Fantastic music in this film. The rapor between Belushi and Aykroyd is great. I believe them as brothers. And I believe them when they say "we're on a mission from God."
Whilst filming, a world record was broken for most amount of cars destroyed in a film. You'll see why when you watch the film. There's never a dull moment in this picture. Jokes, music, slapstick, chases, Nazis, cops, 80s nostalgia hits, it's just great fun. The cast is amazing. Arethra Franklin, Cab Calloway, James Brown, Frank Oz, John Candy, Carrie Fisher, Ray Charles and many more. That is reason alone to see it. I'm constantly quoting this film too. It's one of those. All in all, it's a massive thumbs up from me. This might be in my top 5 favourite films of all time. Just go watch it. 

John candy: "Orange whip? Orange whip?..  Three orange whips!"

Elwood:	There's 106 miles to Chicago, we've got a full tank of gas, half a pack of cigarettes, it's dark out, and we're wearing sunglasses.
Joliet Jake:	Hit it!
I think it has great music in it.
Apart from the scene with the nun and them swearing it's a complete waste of the talents of two otherwise decent performers.
Mon film préféré, un superbe road-trip sur fond de rythm n Blues que mon père m'a fait découvrir quand j'avais 10 ans. Après il faut aimer l'humour absurde mais perso c'est mon cas.
This movie could have been a great one.  Personalities, music and dance and plot.  But it substituted any depth of humor with a lot of crazy violence.
One of the best comedies ever made. Great cast, great car chases, wonderful musical scenes this movie is in a class of its own.
Crazy and hilarious, it is one of the few movies to not mess up when aving so many guest stars !

Although released in 1980, this movie is really the best musical of the 1970's. Combine three of the greatest musicians of all-time, creating three of the most magical musical scenes ever (not to mention Cab Calloway and John Lee Hooker) with two legendary comedians at the top of their game, and you have a movie that is the perfect time capsule of the best of that time. Toss in Carrie Fisher and John Candy, and you have a movie that is a full Three Orange Whips.
The best musical ever made. It's hilarious and extremely entertaining. A must watch!
Don't know why it took me so long to see this.

I am forced to give this movie at least an 8/10, or else my mother would be disappointed in me. It definitely has a lot of charm. John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd has great chemistry together. The story is fun and catchy throughout. Overall a very entertaining movie that will be enjoyed by most.
CLASSIC. Two icon actors successfully delivery a stand out performance. A must watch.

Very interesting and unexpected intro with all the factories and pollution in the air. With the sun barely peeking through all the crap, it almost looks like a desolate planet. It definitely captures the gloominess of it all. I was not expecting the amount of detail and beauty there is to the cinematography in this movie. 

They tore the inside of that mall up. Classic scene in movie history. Pretty impressive how they showed the Nazi movement alive in modern day Chicago. I love the transition from a party full of people with no culture to streets of Chicago, filled with culture. 

I love how the argument at the restaurant turned into a musical number. Brilliant. That Ray Charles cameo was amazing. Wasn't expecting that. The humor is so spot on, outlandish, witty. Amazing how they got all these talented and famous artists like Ray Charles, Cab Calloway and Aretha Franklin as well as the others on instruments. 

So many crazy cop car stunts. This movie gives zero fucks and it's great. So chaotic at times. The exaggeration levels are prime, especially towards the end. It's fucking hilarious. 

One of the funniest movies I've seen in a while.
Very outrageous and funny. Loved Aretha Franklin bit.
One of the best films ever made
The Blues Brothers successfully blends catchy music and Dan Aykroyd style of humor.

Ok mediocre movie starring John belushi and Dan I can't spell his last name aka the guy from Ghostbusters. I'm not a big blues or jazz person so the movie doesn't really connect with me like it did my dad. I'll most likely forget about this movie.
Highly entertaining mischief full of music, propellent sequence of dramatic and humorous situations and a record-breaking number of pile-ups (mostly police cars).
Awesome soundtrack and musical numbers throughout make it a fun enjoyable ride... on a mission from God !!

A surprisingly large number of movies have been based on Saturday Night Live sketches over the years. The Blues Brothers was one of the more critically successful of these films. The Blues Brothers begins with Jake Blue being released from prison, only to find that the orphanage where he and his brother Elwood grew will close in less than 2 weeks if the pair cannot raise $5,000 in legitimate money to pay outstanding property taxes. Their quest to rebuild their old band and raise this money by playing R&B inadvertently pits them against the police, the neo-Nazis, a rival country-western band, and a surprisingly well-armed young woman of unknown motives. Along the way, there will be lots of car chases and musical numbers.

I'm not much of a music critic, but the musical numbers in The Blues Brothers were some of my favorite parts of the film. The best musical numbers implore the audience to buy a copy of the soundtrack and listen to the music independently of the film, and this film made me take a serious interest in the artists whose work is on display. Some of these artists even appear in the film, as, against resistance from the studio, the creators wisely cast notable soul musicians in many of the supporting roles. Even the two leads, John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd, who are better known as actors, had substantial musical experience. The dancing in these scenes is also nicely choreographed, with characters performing flips and leaping into the air, and often involves an impressive number of extras.

The other highlight of the film is undoubtedly the car chases. Allegedly, The Blues Brothers broke the record for the largest number of automobiles destroyed in a film shoot. The first car chase is impressive enough, with the cars crashing through a shopping mall in a scene which is both exciting and chock full of product placement ("The new Oldsmobiles are in early this year!"). By the finale, however, the scale of the car chases has reached ludicrous levels, with seemingly everyone in the state gunning for the brothers. 

As the film's origin as a recurring sketch on SNL would suggest, The Blues Brothers is a comedy, and the film contains some genuinely amusing moments. Even the car chases are filmed in a comedic manner, with slapstick sensibilities. My favorite comedic moment, however, is the result of Jake cursing in the presence of the nun in charge of the orphanage. Kathleen Freeman, incidentally, gives the nun an air of righteous menace despite being the source of the humor in that scene, a dichotomy I quite enjoy. The jokes in the film are also, with a couple notable exceptions, free of adolescent sexual or toilet humor. The worst criticism I can levy against The Blues Brothers is that some of the antagonists are perhaps a tad underutilized - we know nothing about the country band except that they don't have a union permit - although even this is a reach. Otherwise, The Blues Brothers has a trifecta - good music, good jokes, and good action.

This movie is one of those classics that everyone should see. Let me say this: I am glad I experienced it, but I didn't see anything special. The story was good, it made sense and it was a nice idea. The thing is though there wasn't anything juicy on this bone. Sure, the music scenes were pretty cool but they got stale over the time of the film. The comedy was solidâ¦when there was some, it probably lasted for about 45 minutes total and the rest was either filler or music. It did, however, had a good cast and supporting cast, making the movie so much more enjoyable. Sadly, a good cast doesn't help the fact that I was completely bored throughout.

The Blues brothers is a musical comedy directed by John Landis. Very good acting especially Dan Aykroyd as Elwood Blues and John Belushi as Jake Blues. Very good and fun characters especially the Blues brothers. good chemistry between the Blues brothers. Really good cinematography with some exemplary shots. Good settings. Very good set design and props with the cars and the buildings. Very good costume design that is colourful and stylish. Very good style with the colour and how the characters and scenery look. Very good practical effects especially with the car crashes. Very good action even though no one really gets hurt. Steady sound design. Very good dialogue that fits the film nicely.  Steady editing. Really good music with some really good dance scenes. The film also has a simple but fun story. Great comedy that has me burst out laughing. The film is also really enjoyable. Over all I give it a 8/10 - worth paying for two tickets
Great songs, several legendary cameo performances, and the typically dry silly comedy of Belushi make this a cult classic.

Are there movies that get better with time?  YES. So many musical legends of the 20th century together in one movie, incredible music and some over-the-top zany skits & car action because a movie's gotta movie. What a stunning epic performance by all involved.

Warning! Don't see this film!!!  The rest of your life will be anticlimax! It's SOOOO good!!  This is how films should be made!!!  It's cool! It's hot!! And how! And only the very finest guests for these two cool dudes!  Nothing's too good! They're all there! What music!

 I had forgotten how wonderfully good this movie is!  In every way! This cannot be topped! It's so cool! It's so fun! It's so exciting! It's
 so silly! It's so...everything!! You will notice I'm ending each comment with a !   I haven't used too many !!!!s. There aren't enough in the world!  Only 5 stars. Miserable. Give it 500 stars, 1000 are too few!  As Wayne of Wayne's World would say 'we're not worthy!, we're not worthy!

I'm not surprised by the lukewarm response many critics had for this film, because it's not a film for critics. It is, in short, a real film, a film for audiences. This offbeat, haphazard comedy has got to be my favourite film. The cast is fantastic, with hidden gems like John Candy and Henry Gibson. The soundtrack is excellent, championed by Franklin, Brown and Charles. And most importantly the film doesn't take itself too seriously, veering from sardonic humour to slapstick flawlessly. Love it. Over and over again.
The best comedy movie ever made! With the best movie song ever sung: Think! And the best movie quote ever spoken: "We're on a mission from God."

There are few comedies that I can watch over and over again and the Blues Brothers is one that never gets old. Although many site Animal House the Blues Brothers is John Belushi's best film in his short time in the spotlight. Dan Aykroyd and Belushi are perfect as two brothers who must save an orphanage using only their music to do so. The music in this film is the best of any movie and will have you humming it long after you see it. The humor is also unforgettable ranging from pathetic Illinois Nazi's to crazy X's with bazookas. Everyone and his brother cameos in the film as well and if you haven't seen it before there is a surprise around every seen. If you want to see what a true and REAL diverse film is like 35 years before people started virtue signaling about it watch the Blues Brothers, current films are garbage compared to this masterpiece.

Movie night with Iris.

Loved watching this with my daughter. She was enchanted by it's brash bravado and upbeat soundtrack.

This is one of my all time favorite movies.

Elwood: It's 106 miles to Chicago, we got a full tank of gas, half a pack of cigarettes, it's dark... and we're wearing sunglasses.

Jake: Hit it.
Great film. Great moments. Some great music in it.
Awesome film love it
A classic that harkens back to the best days of SNL, with lines like "we're on a mission from god"

The absolute best John Belushi movie and one of the top Aykroyd films, if you are a casual fan of either, or just want a laugh, this is a great movie to go to. And that's not even accounting the amazing soundtrack of some classic blues and soul.

Una Divertida pareja logra mostrar una historia muy leve que es rescatada por el gran encanto de sus protagonistas, Culmina siendo una de las parejas emblemáticas del cine y dando momentos para recordar.

This is one of my all time favourite films. 
I was definitely way to young to watch this when I first saw it, so a lot of the humour went straight over my head. Now I'm older I'm able to appreciate everything more. 
Brilliant acting from John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd. Great music, fantastic car chase scenes, and amazing comedy. I'm not into musicals at all, but somehow something about this film just makes it work for me.

For me watching the film, there wasn't that wave of nostalgia,that often envelopes in many reviewers criticism or critiques. I surprisingly came into this movie with an open mind. However was left disappointed, surmounted with an excessive number of expectations. The Blues Brothers is a decent film, however the premise goes on far too long. If the movie was an hour and a half rather than two and a half, I would've given it a higher score. The characters are all likable, and the beginning angles and dialogue were promising. Yet, as the "story" pressed on their simple minded motive, and repetitive chase scenes became humdrum. Even the spontaneous sing-along numbers became wearisome as some incorporated it into the story, while others played it off as a musical number. I admire the ambition of this movie, but it's execution was sub-par.

Alright, well, here this goes. No, I didn't really like "The Blues Brothers." And that's okay. I don't have to like every movie widely regarded as a classic of the American cinematic arts. In fact, I can plainly see why this one is so sweepingly adored. The infectious dance numbers, the joy-inducing cameos, the bombastic set pieces. It's all fairly enjoyable and - in fact - I enjoyed a lot of it. It's just that, even though there's a general throughline here, there's also this episodic nature to the majority of the second act that didn't really dazzle me in any way. Jake and Elwood have to go to X place and get X person to do X, they do it, and then have to go to X place and get X person to do X as well. It's all too piecemeal for my tastes. But, again, there's still a lot here to be enjoyed and "enjoy" I did (for the most part).
movie that's quite a classic, I understand why, but at the same time, it's not something I enjoyed watching

I grew up watching this film on VHS repeatedly with my brothers so I can quote most of it verbatim.  Even setting that aside though it's still really funny, even when it comes in at over 2hrs (generally a big mistake for a comedy).  The songs are great (this is as close to any musical I'll ever enjoy) and it really hasn't dated.  It truly takes the mantra of 'go big or go home', the budget must have been huge for it's day.  But the SNL base of the comedy is a real success, really brilliant.

Way more of a parody than a comedy, and a very long one at that. I know I'm going to be in the minority here, but I could not get into this at all. A comedy is supposed to make you laugh, not make you roll your eyes which is what I pretty much did throughout this. I've laughed at parodies before, I love me some Leslie Nielsen, but this... nope, nope, nope. The whole side thing with Carrie Fisher as a terrorist with stormtrooper aim was more bizarre than anything else. Also,  how can you have a movie called the Blues Brothers and not feature B.B. King??? James Brown, Ray Charles and Aretha Franklin are great sure, but that's soul music. Ah well, nitpicky me I know. Maybe B.B. didn't want to be in this stinker is my guess.

Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi star in the SNL movie the Blues Brothers. Jake Blues (Belushi) recently out of prison has one objective, get the band together. They are trying to raise 5,000 dollars to save their own catholic school. He and his brother Elwood (Aykroyd), start going across different restaurants and bars all in an effort to get the band together. 

Despite some resistance from some of the former crew, they assemble.
In the process, they do nothing short of enraging cops, driving through a Nazi rally and pissing off quite a few rednecks. They also have an assassin (Carrie Fischer) trying to kill them. There are quite a few musical numbers as well. They have to put it all together and give quite a performance as they manage to fill a venue of 5,000 folks. The film shows some range with a pretty respectable action chase sequence as well. 

Blues Brothers is an understated and original comedy. The film never tries to be over the top and aim for slapstick, or really any other bits. The film simply presents itself and has you determine if you find it funny or not. Some of the funniest parts for the film for me were the constant assassination attempts by Fischer that failed, and the Blues Brothers just keep on going as if nothing happened. The musical numbers are never expected, but they fit the film well and include various musicians from James Brown, Aretha Franklin, and Ray Charles to give the film some heart and soul. Blues Brothers is a tough film to diagnose and I respected it more for the manner at which it was presented than I did the movie itself. I can't help but wonder if I would have enjoyed this film more at the height of its popularity and when the characters were more popular on SNL. In any case Belushi is so charismatic somehow, he carries the film. 

-2.10.2017
Not funny at all. Adequate as a road trip movie, good music, but mislabeled as a comedy.

This is the greatest film ever made. Yes, it's a Saturday night live film. Yes, it's 2 and a half hours of car chases and r&b numbers. And that's what makes it succeed so well. The two main actors are perfect in their roles. I am not a big fan of dan aykroyd, but he does very well here. Not only that, there are abundant cameos from some of the greatest actors and blues musicians of all time. It is, put simply, a movie you never want to end. Yes, it's stupid, and for some people, runs way too long, but it's all about music and it's simply fantastic. A must watch movie.

To set the stage, it is probably worth mentioning that I have never been a regular viewer of SNL, so I was only familiar with the characters of The Blues Brothers tangentially through passing references in pop culture. I genuinely didn't know what to expect with their film, and was somewhat surprised by what I got. There are really 3 big aspects to this film that a viewer can enjoy, and 2 of them worked great. Sadly, the one aspect of The Blues Brothers that didn't click for me was probably the most important one...the comedy. I didn't find the humor all that funny. I might have chuckled once after a prat fall. But most of the silly behavior and other odd things they included, while I could see they were shooting for a laugh, didn't elicit one from me. The joy of this film is that it doesn't rely totally on those jokes that fell flat. The 2nd big aspect of the movie is that it has some superb music. They sprinkle legendary singers throughout the cast and give them the opportunity to show what truly great music is all about. These musical breaks were by far the high points of The Blues Brothers, and had me tapping my toes. What took me completely by surprise was the 3rd big element you will find throughout The Blues Brothers...the quantity, length, and complexity of the car chases. I would guess that at least half the budget must have gone to getting cars to wreck and stunt drivers, because these scenes are everywhere in the film. I'm always impressed by genuine (pre-computer graphics) stunts, and these drivers pulled off some great ones.

While there were a couple elements of the film that I liked, I had a struggle identifying with or caring about the main characters. This film features a pair of protagonists who are the worst con men ever, they are criminals, and they seem uncaring about hurting the people around them. In other words, they're selfish jerks. Then they use the excuse of "a mission from God" to justify their continued selfish actions. We are presented with a motive that is supposed to appear altruistic so that we will be on their side, but I didn't see the virtue in this Catholic home that made it such a worthy cause. Of course, I have to remember this is all comedy. As a result, I'm probably putting too much thought and logic into the setup and just need to roll with it. Yet, even in a comedy, I feel like they owe me the opportunity of liking the protagonists. Complaints aside, there was enough fun stuff going on in The Blues Brothers that I enjoyed watching it. It's certainly not a film I will seek out again, but I think I can see the elements that made many people fall in love with the characters back in the 80s.

A classic I've been yearning to see for a very long time. The Blues Brothers met all my expectations in terms of humor and music. The script is incredibly funny and the tunes are greatly enjoyable. It's comprehensible why this film came to be iconic.

A memorable musical comedy, always enjoyable, it has aged quite well.  A good cast, flimsy but not stupid plot, many good gags, evocative corners of Chicago, and some overlong car chases. Above all, great musical moments across a full range of genres,  and a real sense of collective fun.

More than an SNL comedy; it's music as religion.

The Blues Brothers is directed by John Landus, and it stars John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd in a musical comedy about Jake (John Belushi) who got out of prison, and with his brother Elwood (Dan Aykroyd), they went to an orphan place which they found out that they need to raise $5,000 to pay the bill. The first thing they did, is go to a church to find some answers, and when a light went to Jake, he found out an idea, which is to bring back the band as he think is "a mission from God." The Blues Brothers is one of the rare SNL movies that did well financially and critically, and it makes sense as it holds up still. John Belushi and John Aykroyd are really good and have interesting interplay with each other. The songs that they play are really memorable, which is funny that in some times they just play it at random. The writing by John Landus and Dan Aykroyd is really good, and it brings some humor to it in an over the top way, even if it's trying too hard at times to make it funny. The car chases are entertaining to watch, and the crashes are enjoyably over the top. The characters are memorable, and it has some great cameos. The Blues Brothers is a really great movie that will always be a cult classic.

The Blues Brothers is a classic comedy that can be over the top sometimes, but is made up from stellar performances, great music numbers, and great comedy that contains more than enough to fill in the gaps.

Having heard the soundtrack to this movie throughout my childhood but having never seen the film this film was always on a list of films i had to see. "It's 106 miles to Chicago, we got a full tank of gas, half a pack of cigarettes, it's dark and we're wearing sunglasses..."

It's always a tricky one when you revisit a film that was a big part of your adolescence and in some ways responsible for laying the groundwork on your love of movies. There's likely to be a tinge of nostalgia or reminiscence, making it difficult to judge it objectively. That said, sometimes the film is just so much fun and so enjoyable that you know why you hold it in such high regard in the first place. Without a shadow of a doubt, The Blues Brothers is (still) that kind of film.

When "Joliet" Jake Blues (John Belushi) is released from prison, he and his brother Elwood (Dan Aykroyd) pay a visit to the old Catholic home where they grew up. They soon find out that the orphanage is to be shut down due to lack of funds. As a result, Jake and Elwood go on a mission to re-form their old blues band and raise the money required.

Say what you will about the comedic talents of Will Ferrell, Adam Sandler or Mike Myers but they share something in common in terms of making their name on comedy sketch show Saturday Night Live. These names are just three of the shows recent successful comedians but having, personally, been born in the late 70's and grew up throughout the 80's, most of the comedies I was exposed to were filled with the familiar faces that actually had a hand in the origins of this show - Chevy Chase, Bill Murray, Steve Martin, Eddie Murphy and, of course, John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd. In fact, The Blues Brothers is an adaptation of a short sketch that first aired on Saturday Night Live and is one of only two successful film adaptations from the show - the other being Wayne's World.

However, despite this films success, it was actually fraught with production problems and a budget that got way out control. Firstly, Dan Aykroyd's script was a massive 324 pages (three times longer than a normal screenplay) which he jokingly bound in the cover of the Yellow Pages before delivering it to John Landis to edit it down. Also, Landis' outlandish car chases and vehicular pile-up's throughout the end of the film sent the budget $10million over it's initial $17.5. This wasn't helped by John Belushi's spiralling drug habit which would cause him to disappear for lengthy periods from the set.

These issues aside, though, The Blues Brothers still struck a chord with audiences and critics alike - even the Vatican gave it the thumbs-up for being a good Catholic movie - and it has since went on to become a cult classic. Over 30 years later, it's easy to see why...

The story doesn't really amount to very much but the titular characters are hard to resist as they ooze a laid-back cool, dressed in their iconic black suits and dark Ray-Bans - a good ten years before Tarantino's similarly attired Reservoir Dogs. Jake and Elwood manage to get themselves in all sorts of scrapes and upset a whole horde of different people; a machine gun, bazooka wielding disgruntled ex-girlfriend (Carrie Fisher), the Illinois Nazi Party, country band The Good Ol' Boys and, not to mention, the sheer tally of cops, all in hot pursuit. It's riotously over the top and when the film reaches it's denouement it has already crossed the ridiculous border but Landis and Aykroyd know this. They simply don't care. And that's what makes the film so enjoyable. There's an unashamedly free-spirited nature to the proceedings which is highly infectious but nothing entertains more than the magnificent musical numbers from a choice selection of Soul and R&B talents. Among the many toe-tapping highlights are Aretha Franklin's "Think", Cab Calloway's "Minnie the Moocher", John Lee Hooker's "Boom Boom" and the great Ray Charles with "Shake a Tail Feather". 

The Blues Brothers has stood the test of time and truly is one of a kind. It's provides action, laughs and song and dance numbers that haven't aged a bit. It's admittedly raucous, loud and chaotic but as far as I'm concerned, anything goes when you're "on a mission from God".

Un classico intramontabile che non smetterà mai di farmi ridere dopo tutto questo tempo. Il suo umorismo molto particolare si sposa perfettamente con due protagonisti geniali e una sceneggiatura perfetta. La sintonia tra i due attori principali, le musiche estremamente coinvolgenti, il pazzo umorismo e l'esagerazione generale rendono il film unico nel suo genere, una vera perla del cinema che merita certamente più attenzione di quanta ne abbia già ricevuta. Mi ricorderò per sempre di "The Blues Brothers", un film che mi mette allegria al solo pensiero, senza dubbio tra i miei film preferiti di sempre.

John Landis delivers us a memorable cult with hilarious stunts, perfectly played characters, and of course, some good music.
Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi portray their Saturday Night Live characters in a fashion that is so great that no other actors possible could replace them. Elwood (Aykroyd) is a laid back harmonica player, who even though has a record of driving recklessly, can still be trusted by any other fellow friend or musician, and his brother, Joliet Jake Blues (Belushi). Jake, who has been released from Joliet Prison, and has reunited with his brother, along with a scheme up his sleeve.
Jake wants to reunite ''the band'', and Elwood takes some time to think about if The Blues Brothers should reunite, or if he should continue selling cars for microphones, and commencing car chases inside of malls. 
Elwood decides. Of course, the band must be united, but sadly, the band members, who are real-life, talented musicians, have gone their separate ways. The brothers then go all out in Chicago to find and bribe their members help make The Blues Brothers have a great return. 
I must say, this movie is odd. It's weird. Somehow, John Landis and his incredible cast manage to deliver us a film that has a brilliant flow and memorable scenes that we can't help but like it. First of all, the comedy is hilarious. It's hard to make a lot of people laugh, and The Blues Brother's cracked me up. The car chase scenes were hysterical. I'll bet anyone that more cars were destroyed in this film than the first season of ''The Dukes of Hazzard''.
Speaking of that great cast, you will see plenty of notable musicians and actors, such as Aretha Franklin, Cab Galloway, James Brown, Ray Charles, Steve Lawrence, John Candy, and even Steven Spielberg.
Yes, you will see plenty of bizarre, and not to mention, random things in The Blues Brothers. If you're up to seeing cars being crushed, a city's police force going insane, rednecks, an insane Nun, and ''Illinois Nazis'', than you will love this film.
An over-the-top comedy with some excellent musician cameos. The Blues Brothers has wonderful charm and is a good collaboration of the comedy and musical genres.

If you don't like this movie, I'm glad I don't know you. Nor would I want to know you. Made during the times when movies weren't decided to be made by corporate committees, as they are these days.

It's silly. It's over-the-top. It's one long gag reel for Saturday Night Live. It's an excuse for music videos. And yet, this film is.... perfect. It works. Probably because the filmmakers were on a mission, from God.

The Blues Brothers are Jiolet Jake and Elwood Blues. When Jake is released from prison and reteams with Elwood, they find that an orphanage needs $5000 in order to continue functioning. Believing this fundraiser is a mission from God, the Brothers put together their old rhythm and blues band, and dodge Illinois Nazis, Good Ole Boys, Jake's ex-girlfriend and the Law as they try desperately to put on a show for the ages.

SNL alum John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd reprise their roles from the sketch comedy show as Jake and Elwood, while a who's who of the music and film worlds join them in the cast - Cab Calloway, Carrie Fisher, Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles, James Brown, John Candy, Kathleen Freeman, Twiggy, Frank Oz, Steven Spielberg, John Lee Hooker and Joe Walsh all appear in the cast. In addition, some of America's finest session musicians appear as the Blues Brothers band - Steve Cropper, Donald "Duck" Dunn, Murphy Dunne, Willie Hall, Bones Malone, Blue Lou Marini, Matt "Guitar" Murphy and Alan Rubin all lend their talents.

Then there's the music - Ray Charles plays "Shake a Tail Feather", Aretha Franklin lets loose on her classic hit "Think", James Brown sings a gospel tune, and the Blues Brothers play everything from "Theme from Rawhide" to "Everybody Needs Somebody To Love" and "Sweet Home Chicago". The soundtrack is arguably the best in Hollywood, no questions asked.

The jokes are on-point, every line is quotable - it's a cult classic. There's no avoiding that. A magnificent, brilliant film.

A timeless classic which will live on through the decades to come!

The Blues Brothers is not a movie built around a strong story line, nor is it meant to be. The Blues Brothers is a perfectly eccentric vehicle that drives a combination of outlandish antics, blues culture and the wholly unrealistic adventure of Jake and Elwood Blues. John Belushi as Jake Blues is the peak of his dynamic career. Blues greats like Ray Charles and Aretha Franklin perform dynamite cameos that hammer in the soul flavor. Tie it in with the wildly over-the-top car chases and funky dance numbers, and you'll find that the director accomplishes exactly what he sets out for: a massively ridiculous and charming film of mayhem and music.

Mesmerizing musical cum comedy !

It's over the top, and it seems more focused on style and car chases, but it's the style and unpredictable humour that, in my opinion, reinforce this film's appeal. The plot can be a little difficult to follow sometimes, mainly because the film tends to get sidetracked by all the wacky, seemingly random gags and characters. While some of the jokes can seem random, it's not a machine gun of comedy, and at least the jokes have some relevance to the plot, even if that relevance comes later on. The performances from the film's main cast are very good, even if some of the characters aren't as special, and I find the main characters to be really appealing. The film certainly knows how to flaunt its style, which I might have expected from a film called "The Blues Brothers". Speaking of that, the film's musical style is a whimsical combination of old blues and R&B, which works well with the film's atmosphere. For me, the best part of the film is its final scenes, which all add up to one truly zany spectacle. If you're interested in seeing a movie that's different to anything else out there, I'd give this movie a good look.
Great music with the most insanely over the top ending I think I have ever seen in any comedy. Love every moment of it.
Great music, awesome cast, and an outrageous plot that, while retaining the nostalgia, unfortunately doesn't hold up visually.

One of those movies that will make you wonder "how the hell did this ever get made?" In a good way. In a great way. Great comedy, great music, perfect timing. I recommend seeing the extended version over the theatrical which is butchered due to incredibly poor test-screenings back in the day (can you believe that?) A classic. Must see.

A ludicrous comedy based off the popular SNL sketch that mostly succeeds in delivering the laughs, but excels big time in hilarious, on-screen destruction! The running joke that the Blues Brothers are invincible and don't react to any of their surroundings is hysterical and the destruction is expertly filmed. It did take a while to get going (partly because I could only find the extended edition), but it became a toe-tapping, good time by the end. The celebrity cameos are also great with a truly gut-busting moment from Ray Charles, and a psychotic ex-wife hunting the boys down, played by Carrie Fisher! There are a few moments where the jokes don't hit and towards the end some cartoony moments come out of nowhere, but it's a fun time and definitely one of the better SNL-adaptations.
"we're on a mission from God"
funny, satirical and classic

An Action Musical comedy, as well as a government failure satire. Can you imaging that Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles, James Brown, and John Lee Hooker all gathered in one movie? Let alone "Princess Leia!" Definitely a must-see.
I hate Illinois Nazis, but I love the Blues Brothers. It's one of the most quotable movie I've seen, and also the most destructive. Michael Bay, take notes!
A classic in so many ways with multiple great car chases (one through a mall, the other through downtown Chicago), wonderful musical numbers, and lots of funny gags.
One of the best movies ever!
Finally got around to watching this wasn't disappointed :)
One of my all-time favorites going back to childhood.   There has never been a movie anything like The Blues Brothers.   Uproarious, playful, brilliant comedy.  RIP John Belushi
The Blues Brothers works as both a musical comedy and a slapstick comedy
A hilarious action packed musical that's a must see for anyone who appreciates music.
my favorite film of all time, this film is a classic

The Blues Brothers is indulgent, over the top, and occasionally ludicrous. But with a quick witted sense of humor and an all time great soundtrack, this SNL duo transcends its faults and becomes a tour hour jolt of pure fun and blues.
Awesome soundtrack and good humor. One of best SNL films
We're on a mission from God, nuff said.
"We're on a mission from God."

Belushi and Akroyd deliver the script's jokes with such deadpan neutrality that the already impeccable script is bolstered even further. One of the most quotable movies of all time, the film succeeds as a comedy, musical and road trip film all in one.
An enjoyable and chaotic road trip comedy filled with catchy music numbers and memorable car chases
The greatest musical movie of all time. I still hate Illinois Nazis.

Usually, overdoing stuff in movies may affect the film's level. That's what happened in this film in its chases, but the climax with the overdoing element has a funny effect that was acceptable, even though it wasn't following the rules of gravity in a few times. Besides that element, the film's comedic and musically energy comes partly from its duo's "serious" performances as they are good, next to some nice numbers. (B+)

(Full review coming soon)

The Blues Brothers is an iconic film and I had wanted to see it for a very long time, but never got around to it, and I am glad I finally did. This is an excellent comedy that is brilliantly acted and directed and it has many memorable moments that standout. The pairing of Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi is terrific, and they have great chemistry. The film blends well thought out comedy with an entertaining musical numbers that are far better than any other musical film that I have seen. I must confess I never was the biggest fan of musicals, I found them to be average at best, entertaining depending on what was written in the script, but never anything memorable either. With the Blues Brothers, it's quite different, there are enough moments of dialogue here to compliment the musical numbers, and it makes for a truly engaging film that is entertaining from start to finish.  I really enjoyed the film, it was a finely executed blend of comedy and music and it has to rank among one of the finest genre films ever made. The script is solid, and thoroughly entertaining, and the viewer is sucked into its humorous and memorable plot that is elevated by Aykroyd's and Belushi screen chemistry. Something simple goes a long way, and in the case of this film, it proves exactly right. The Blues Brothers in terms of story is nothing elaborate, but where it stands out, are the performances by its leads. The chemistry between the two lead actors is what elevates the simple plot to greatness and it's a fun; entertaining picture that in the long run is a memorable piece of comedy. The Blues Brothers is a must see film, a terrific performance by Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi , of which Belushi delivers a highly memorable performance, one that defined his sadly too short career.

Man, the seventies must have sucked. But they did have some darn good music... The plot here is pretty incoherent, but the many cameos are pretty great. And they destroy a ridiculous number of cars...
Great Comedy Classic has strong language and criminal brothers. Ages 14+
The music is still fresh and the jokes are still funny. An all-time classic.
Too much isn't enough.  watching it many times revisits situational comedy endlessly.  love it!
How can you not love The Blues Brothers. The Blues Brothers are just gods in every category, and the movie shows that. The movie is a major hit, songs, etc.

It's funny and entertaining and has good songs to enjoy
A spirited film with plenty to go around.
I grew up on this movie. If it wasn't for this movie and it's great music and just overall great filming and story line I would not be the man I am today

When I realized that this movie was over two hours long, I thought, "How on earth are they going to make an interesting comedy that stretches that long?!?" What I forgot is that one of the things that people love about this movie is the musical numbers. With all of the over-the-top car chases, ominous nuns, and clever quips in this film, there are also some absolutely fantastic musical cameos from the likes of Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles and Cab Calloway. Aykroyd and Belushi are a hilarious team in this flick, and the persona that they put on with these well-dressed, fedora-donning singers is perfect. I don't think that Aykroyd's character removes his sunglasses for the entire film, and we only see Belushi's character do so for a particularly interesting scene near the end. We don't end up knowing much about these characters, and that's exactly the way that this movie is supposed to be executed; they are supposed to remain a bit mysterious. The movie's ridiculous tone gives itself a hand, as this allows some of the most ludicrous things in the movie, such as how a nun can close a door without touching it or how a car can land the jumps that these two do, to be forgiven by the phrase, "Hey, it's a comedy." My only complaint with this movie is that the chase scene through Chicago City Hall at the end goes on a bit long for an already long movie, and doesn't contain either laughs or music, this film's strong suit. This didn't distract from how fantastic this film was, however, and I would watch it again anytime.
